title: Know Your Customer & Customer Due Diligence Training
headline: Discover how to verify the authenticity of customers' identities and prevent fraudulent acts in this free online course.
description: ‘Know your customer’ (KYC) is a tactical approach to identifying and verifying clients' information and identity to ascertain the genuineness of the clients. Companies must conduct background checks on their clients before giving them access to their services or products. What methods can you use to verify a customer's identity effectively? We'll teach you the concept of KYC, how to verify customers' identities and prevent fraud.
courseDescription:
‘Know your customer’ (KYC) is a significant factor for businesses worldwide in combating financial crimes and fraud today. The KYC process involves various procedures, including ID card verification, document verification (utility bills as proof of address), face verification and more to check if clients are genuine. These procedures are crucial in assessing customer risk and double as legal requirements in complying with anti-money laundering (AML) laws and regulations. So how can these procedures be carried out to determine the validity of clients' information? We'll teach you the concepts of KYC and its procedures in assessing the level of risks involved with each client. We begin by discussing the process of KYC to ascertain the authenticity of clients. Then investigate the objectives of KYC, the KYC compliance framework and its benefits.

One of the ways to perform extensive background checks on clients is to scrutinise all their information for any inconsistencies and anomalies before establishing business relationships with them. To achieve this, you must do proper customer due diligence among many procedures of KYC. First, you will study the components of KYC, including the concept of customer due diligence. Following that, we outline the steps to carry out the KYC verification and the methods of collecting data from documents. In assessing risk, there are transactions that clients may carry out that can indicate the likelihood of risk and danger. This course will help you understand the two types of risk factors and the types of transactions that are risk indicators. Finally, you will learn when it is necessary to carry out extensive verification and monitoring processes on high-risk clients.

Money laundering involves the illegal process of acquiring vast amounts of money through criminal activities such as drug trafficking and terrorism financing. You'll study the stages of money laundering and a couple of examples of each of the stages. Then you'll learn about AML, AML compliance, AML compliance program, AML monitoring and the client onboarding process. Upon that, we show you the various regulatory bodies that govern KYC and AML compliance in different industries. Finally, we discuss the penalties for non-compliance of financial institutions to the KYC and AML regulations. This course is open to business owners, managers, entrepreneurs and anyone in the business and financial sector. By studying this course, you'll discover how to verify the identity of clients and maintain healthy business relations with them to intercept fraudulent activities such as money laundering, terrorism funding and other financial crimes.   • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • KYC is a phrase that means "know your customer." Customers' authenticity is ensured through KYC procedures, which verify their identity to assess danger.
    • Due to KYC and AML regulations, businesses must check their customers before onboarding them.
    • When obtaining KYC information using a risk-based approach, there are four primary objectives to consider: identify the customer, verify the client's true identity, understand the customer's activities and source of funding and monitor the customer's activities regularly.
    • According to global regulatory authorities' regulations, companies worldwide are expected to conduct extensive identity-checking on their clients to prevent financial crime on an organisational and international level.
    • The primary benefit a firm can get by following KYC compliance is avoiding huge fines. A few other benefits are as follows: fraud prevention, regulatory compliance, secure customer onboarding and customer Retention, credibility and Growth.
    • The entire identity verification procedure encompasses a lot; however, the most important ones are the customer identification program, customer due diligence and ongoing monitoring.
    • In the KYC procedure, CDD is classified into three categories depending on the level of risk associated with each person. For example, a person exposed to PEPs (politically exposed person) may require a more thorough screening than regular account holders with low transaction levels: simplified customer due diligence or CDD, standard due diligence or SDD and enhanced due diligence or EDD.
